texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although Citrix recommends against using software RAID with XenServer due to performance issues, I've had some pretty awful experiences with hardware RAID cards over the last few years. In addition, the price of software RAID makes it a very desirable solution.
texts.text: Although Citrix recommends against using software RAID with XenServer due to performance issues, I've had some pretty awful experiences with hardware RAID cards over the last few years. In addition, the price of software RAID makes it a very desirable solution.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you get started,   go through the steps to disable GPT . That post also explains an optional adjustment to get a larger root partition (which I would recommend).  You cannot complete the steps in this post if your XenServer installation uses GPT.
texts.text: Before you get started,   go through the steps to disable GPT . That post also explains an optional adjustment to get a larger root partition (which I would recommend).  You cannot complete the steps in this post if your XenServer installation uses GPT.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You should have three partitions on your first disk after the installation:
texts.text: You should have three partitions on your first disk after the installation:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# fdisk -l /dev/sda
-- SNIP --
   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/sda1   *           1        2611    20971520   83  Linux
/dev/sda2            2611        5222    20971520   83  Linux
/dev/sda3            5222       19457   114345281   8e  Linux LVM
texts.text:
# fdisk -l /dev/sda
-- SNIP --
   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/sda1   *           1        2611    20971520   83  Linux
/dev/sda2            2611        5222    20971520   83  Linux
/dev/sda3            5222       19457   114345281   8e  Linux LVM

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's a quick explanation of your partitions:
texts.text: Here's a quick explanation of your partitions:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='/dev/sda1:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='/dev/sda1:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='/dev/sda2:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='/dev/sda2:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='/dev/sda3:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='/dev/sda3:'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need to replicate the same partition structure across each of your drives and the software RAID volume will span the across the third partition on each disk. Copying the partition structure from disk to disk is done easily with
texts.text: We need to replicate the same partition structure across each of your drives and the software RAID volume will span the across the third partition on each disk. Copying the partition structure from disk to disk is done easily with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sfdisk
texts.text: sfdisk

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: WHOA THERE! NO TURNING BACK!  This step is destructive! If your other disks have any data on them, this step will make it (relatively) impossible to retrieve data on those disks again. Back up any data on the other disks in your XenServer machine before running these next commands.
texts.text: WHOA THERE! NO TURNING BACK!  This step is destructive! If your other disks have any data on them, this step will make it (relatively) impossible to retrieve data on those disks again. Back up any data on the other disks in your XenServer machine before running these next commands.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdb
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdc
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdd
texts.text:
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdb
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdc
sfdisk -d /dev/sda | sfdisk --force /dev/sdd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you have only two disks, stop with
texts.text: If you have only two disks, stop with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /dev/sdb
texts.text: /dev/sdb

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and you'll be making a RAID 1 array. My machine has four disks and I'll be making a RAID 10 array.
texts.text: and you'll be making a RAID 1 array. My machine has four disks and I'll be making a RAID 10 array.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need to destroy the main storage repository, but we need to unplug the physical block device first. Get the storage repository uuid first, then use it to find the corresponding physical block device. Once the physical block device is unplugged, the storage repository can be destroyed:
texts.text: We need to destroy the main storage repository, but we need to unplug the physical block device first. Get the storage repository uuid first, then use it to find the corresponding physical block device. Once the physical block device is unplugged, the storage repository can be destroyed:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# xe sr-list name-label=Local\ storage | head -1
uuid ( RO)                : 75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361
# xe pbd-list sr-uuid=75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361 | head -1
uuid ( RO)                  : ff7e9656-c27c-1889-7a6d-687a561f0ad0
# xe pbd-unplug uuid=ff7e9656-c27c-1889-7a6d-687a561f0ad0
# xe sr-destroy uuid=75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361
texts.text:
# xe sr-list name-label=Local\ storage | head -1
uuid ( RO)                : 75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361
# xe pbd-list sr-uuid=75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361 | head -1
uuid ( RO)                  : ff7e9656-c27c-1889-7a6d-687a561f0ad0
# xe pbd-unplug uuid=ff7e9656-c27c-1889-7a6d-687a561f0ad0
# xe sr-destroy uuid=75264965-f981-749e-0f9a-e32856c46361

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All of the LVM data from
texts.text: All of the LVM data from

texts.orig: /dev/sda3
texts.text: /dev/sda3

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: should now be gone:
texts.text: should now be gone:

texts.orig:
# lvdisplay && vgdisplay && pvdisplay
#
texts.text:
# lvdisplay && vgdisplay && pvdisplay
#

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Change the third partition on each physical disk to be a software RAID partition type:
texts.text: Change the third partition on each physical disk to be a software RAID partition type:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sda
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdb
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdc
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdd
texts.text:
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sda
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdb
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdc
echo -e "t
3
fd
w
" | fdisk /dev/sdd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Stop here and reboot your XenServer box to pick up the new partition changes. Once the server comes back from the reboot, start up a software RAID volume with
texts.text: Stop here and reboot your XenServer box to pick up the new partition changes. Once the server comes back from the reboot, start up a software RAID volume with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mdadm
texts.text: mdadm

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: Check to see that your RAID array is building:
texts.text: Check to see that your RAID array is building:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# cat /proc/mdstat
Personalities : [raid10]
md0 : active raid10 sdd3[3] sdc3[2] sdb3[1] sda3[0]
      228690432 blocks 64K chunks 2 near-copies [4/4] [UUUU]
      [>....................]  resync =  0.3% (694272/228690432) finish=16.4min speed=231424K/sec
texts.text:
# cat /proc/mdstat
Personalities : [raid10]
md0 : active raid10 sdd3[3] sdc3[2] sdb3[1] sda3[0]
      228690432 blocks 64K chunks 2 near-copies [4/4] [UUUU]
      [>....................]  resync =  0.3% (694272/228690432) finish=16.4min speed=231424K/sec

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although you don't have to wait for the resync to complete, just be aware that XenServer doesn't do well with a lot of disk I/O within dom0. You may notice unusually slow performance in dom0 until it finishes. Save the array's configuration for reboots:
texts.text: Although you don't have to wait for the resync to complete, just be aware that XenServer doesn't do well with a lot of disk I/O within dom0. You may notice unusually slow performance in dom0 until it finishes. Save the array's configuration for reboots:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/mdadm.conf
texts.text: /etc/mdadm.conf

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Edit the
texts.text: Edit the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/mdadm.conf
texts.text: /etc/mdadm.conf

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file and append
texts.text: file and append

texts.label: code
texts.orig: auto=yes
texts.text: auto=yes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to the end of the line (but leave everything on one line):
texts.text: to the end of the line (but leave everything on one line):

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid10 num-devices=4 metadata=0.90 \
  UUID=2876748c:5117eed5:ce4d62d3:9592bd84 auto=yes
texts.text:
ARRAY /dev/md0 level=raid10 num-devices=4 metadata=0.90 \
  UUID=2876748c:5117eed5:ce4d62d3:9592bd84 auto=yes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Create a new storage repository on the RAID volume with thin provisioning (thanks to  Spherical Chicken  for the command):
texts.text: Create a new storage repository on the RAID volume with thin provisioning (thanks to  Spherical Chicken  for the command):

texts.label: code
texts.orig: xe sr-create content-type=user type=ext device-config:device=/dev/md0 shared=false name-label="Local storage"
texts.text: xe sr-create content-type=user type=ext device-config:device=/dev/md0 shared=false name-label="Local storage"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This command takes some time to complete since it makes logical volumes and then makes an ext3 filesystem for the new storage repository. Bigger RAID arrays will take more time and it's guaranteed to take longer than you'd expect if your RAID array is still building. As soon as it completes, you'll be given the uuid of your new storage repository and it should appear within the XenCenter interface.
texts.text: This command takes some time to complete since it makes logical volumes and then makes an ext3 filesystem for the new storage repository. Bigger RAID arrays will take more time and it's guaranteed to take longer than you'd expect if your RAID array is still building. As soon as it completes, you'll be given the uuid of your new storage repository and it should appear within the XenCenter interface.

texts.text: TIP: If you run into any problems during reboots, open

texts.text: /boot/extlinux.conf

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: boot section. This removes the framebuffer during boot-up and it causes a lot more output to be printed to the console. It won't affect the display once your XenServer box has fully booted.
texts.text: boot section. This removes the framebuffer during boot-up and it causes a lot more output to be printed to the console. It won't affect the display once your XenServer box has fully booted.
